0.15.text:
Here, below London, 32km of new tunnels are
nearly finished.

4.56.text: But these aren't for people: they're for power.

7.66.text:
Cables carrying 400,000 volts will run through
here,

12.05.text: supporting the city as it keeps growing

13.55.text: and keeps demanding more and more electricity.

16.55.text: This project cost a billion pounds,

19.67.text: all to keep the lights on.

20.81.text: So how did we get to this?

23.00.text:
Back in the 1920s, electricity was generated
by hundreds of small companies

27.72.text: in towns and cities across the country.

29.77.text: They were all different and mostly incompatible:

32.63.text: London alone had 24 voltages and 10 frequencies.

36.47.text: So if you moved to the next street over,

38.76.text: you might have to replace all your light bulbs.

41.01.text: If you had any light bulbs, that is:

42.55.text:
the cost of electricity was out of reach of
nearly everyone.

46.24.text:
Now the answer might have been to do what
other countries in Europe were doing:

49.71.text: set up and enforce standards, regulate prices,

52.90.text: maybe even nationalise the power companies.

55.03.text: And bring the price down for everyone --

56.77.text: people and business. Good plan in theory,

60.62.text:
but the trouble was that the Prime Minister
at the time was Stanley Baldwin,

64.75.text: and he led the Conservative party. Politically,

67.11.text:
he couldn't just assume control of private
corporations!

71.87.text: That was something that the Other Side did.

75.47.text:
So the solution was a very clever and very
British compromise:

79.75.text:
the National Gridiron, later just National
Grid.

85.34.text: backed up by the government and run privately,

88.00.text: would construct and own the central infrastructure.

91.27.text:
It would build a network of transmission lines
sweeping across the country.

95.13.text:
The Grid would reduce the risk for the private
generating companies

98.59.text: and let them reach a much, much, larger market.

101.89.text: If they wanted to connect and reach everyone,

102.89.text:
they had to meet the Grid's standards for
frequency,

111.90.text:
The greatest story I found while I was researching
this is that

115.18.text: originally, there were six separate grid areas

117.15.text: spread all around the country, all run individually.

120.63.text: It was judged too risky by their managers

122.26.text:
to actually connect them all into one National
Grid.

127.43.text:
Sometimes two or maybe even three of those
grid areas were connected

130.75.text:
to help out if one power station somewhere
went down.

133.50.text:
So on the night of 29th October, 1937, without
any permission,

139.04.text:
the engineers in the control rooms quietly
decided

141.92.text:
to connect the whole country together for
an hour or two

146.15.text: And it worked. And a year later,

148.14.text: even their managers agreed: it was the only way

150.23.text: to make sure the lights stayed on everywhere.

153.50.text: And so while the level of regulation,

158.87.text:
as it has in pretty much every country in
the world --

162.18.text:
and while the technology has developed to
the point

164.81.text: that instead of laying transmission lines,

167.02.text:
we are now in billion-pound tunnelling projects
60m under London,

171.50.text:
that mostly-private grid is what we still
have today.

174.11.text: It's listed on the London Stock Exchange.

176.36.text: If history had turned out differently,

179.38.text:
perhaps this tunnel would have been a government
operation:

183.58.text:
we'd have still needed this to keep the lights
on.

186.73.text: Thank you very much to the National Grid

188.58.text:
and all the folks who've helped bring me down
to the Power Tunnels,

193.41.text: who's done a video about these tunnels themselves

195.97.text: and all the infrastructure around me.

197.60.text: Go check that out on his channel!
